data.title: Very good food
data.text:
Stopped for lunch and sat at outside table. Surprisingly good food Guatemala cuisine.
We had the Grill Shrimp and the Shrimp scamp style both delicious.
Excellent chips, salsa and tortilla.

data.title: Say Ciao to Ortegas
data.text: I dined here twice…once for breakfast which consisted of two eggs and runny beans.  Tasted terrible and looked worst.  Second time attended an opening celebration…you'd think that they would do a great job since they were promoting themselves.  Again food almost inedible.

data.title: Great Food
data.text: used them for catering at work - the food was delicious and the service was excellent too! Authentic food, served in nice appropriate sizes for the business mixer we were hosting.

data.title: Good food, atmosphere lacking.
data.text:
Good food, but can be difficult to order, if you don't speak fluent Spanish. It depends on who is there.

The food is always fresh, and it is tasty, especially if you are vegetarian/vegan. The salsa is fresh made daily and is delicious.

The staff normally accommodates special requests.

The margaritas are real, no fake sour mix..all natural ingredients. I add fresh oj to my margaritas, as they actually use dump oranges into a really cool acting juicing machine:).

The atmosphere is quite lacking, so don't go if that is important to you.

data.title: Our New Favorite Place to Go
data.text: Authentic Guatemalan food. Very homemade, even the tortillas delicious. I always get their Chicken soup which is a meal, comes with a grilled chicken leg and rice. the other dish I've had is the Tortilla de Herina Mixta also fabulous. The warm homemade rice pudding is very good too. My husband had the Guisado de ris which was very tender and a nice size portion. He also had the breakfast dish Huevos with Chorizo comes with refried beans, sour cream, plantains (best I've ever had), and homemade tortillas. You never leave hungry.

data.title: Excellente!
data.text:
The owners are Guatemalan as is the majority of the menu. We chose the papusas, the national dish of El Salvador as we will be traveling there I'm a few weeks. Papusas are a sort of pancake stuffed with refried beans, cheese, or different meats. These were absolutely delicious! Get the combination plate to try the different varieties.

The staff was incredibly friendly and the owner checked with us twice during the meal. This is a place where the details matter. The family travels back to their home village in Guatemala where they have a coffee plantation. They return with their own special blend to serve at the restaurant. The best part was that five of us ate for $75 including a generous tip.

data.title: Certainly shouldn't be ranked so low
data.text: Ortega's is the best restaurant, by far, in Downtown Danbury. Pleasant and friendly service; exquisite, family-based Guatemalan food (the real stuff!); and a neighborhood buzz, where non-alikes mingle and laugh. I'd actually give it a 4+. They are family, in many ways.

data.title: Great Grilled Chicken
data.text: Thoroughly enjoyed my grilled chicken dish. Taste like it came right off my grill at home. I would have preferred if they would have pounded the chicken breast before cooking it because it was a bit too thick. It came with rice and black beans. We also had chips and salsa. Limited parking is on the street, pack some quarters for the meters. Restaurant was a bit too noisy for our liking due to employees kids sitting in the adjoining booths playing their video games a bit too loud. Also, a nearby pool table game was too loud as well. Great food though, so we will be back and just be a bit more discriminatory when choosing a seat.

data.title: Little Place On Ives, Worth The Trip
data.text:
First off, do not be put off by the location or the size of Ortegas; Ives St. used to be "Restaurant Row" but now there are only a few left. Ortegas is one of the survivors and they are worth a visit.
The signage says Diner and Restaurant and may be off-putting but stroll on in anyway. The staff are all family and extremely friendly and are truly happy to see you and invite you into their establishment.
From the outside you could be fooled into thinking that it serves Mexican cuisine but the owners are Guatemalan and the food is as authentic as you can get outside of Villa Nueva.
Since they are within walking distance of the business district, the menu shows breakfast options as well as lunch and dinner choices. We went for the evening's special which was a chicken and vegetable platter, very much like a stew; it also could be served with shrimp if that was your liking.
The Tamales are classic Guatemalan, rich and satisfying and nothing like their Mexican cousins to the north. They are vegetable or chicken and are moist and flavorful. Along those lines, the Fajitas are spiced for the Guatemalan  taste and are subtle but fascinating at the same time.
Everything is hand made, on the premises and one of the examples of the care taken in preparation is the tortillas. They are a hybrid, both corn and flour, hand thrown and shaped. Not at all like the thin commercial tortillas that are served in other restaurants or sold in the stores; these are thicker and have a wonderful bread-like texture that stands up to the food or eaten plain, they are that flavorful. I had trouble keeping my family out of my stash, you'll want to order an extra helping if you have that problem as well.
Ortega's is a relatively new place and are absolutely worth your consideration and a visit. If you are a fan of Central American cuisines, or are just looking to try something new, you will not be disappointed with Ortega's.

data.title: A great find!
data.text: We pulled off I-84 to find a place to watch the World Cup and this was a really great find. The waitress and proprietress were very welcoming and let us find the channels we wanted (they have 2 TVs). The food was quite good -- tasty, not greasy, the salsa looked like it was homemade, as did the tortillas and chips. Recommended!

data.title: Really fantastic 1st visit.
data.text: Just got back from my first visit to this place.  I was the only one in there for an early lunch.  Not sure how much traffic they get.  Hopefully there is a decent dinner crowd because the food was very fresh, hot and mouth-watering.  I think the owner himself waited on me.  I really enjoyed my lunch.  I had this humungous steak burrito (one of the specials) and I had to try the pupusas (which I have never had).  Loved them both and will definitely be back.  Place was clean and neat.
